page.title: 9.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn how to make decisions about the quadratic formula. We will pay close attention to each step in the solving process and analyze errors commonly made when applying the formula. You will need to consider how to verify that the solutions you obtained with the quadratic formula are correct.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Identify common errors when using the quadratic formula.
  • Describe some ways to tell if a number is a solution to a quadratic equation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.7.1: Evaluating Variable Expressions
  • 9.7.2: Common Calculation Errors When Using the Quadratic Formula
    • 9.7.2: Self Check
    • 9.7.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.7.3: Different Methods of Checking Solutions of Quadratic Equations
    • 9.7.3: Self Check
    • 9.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.7.4: Practice Spotting Calculation Errors

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.7.5: Practice
  • 9.7.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.7.1: Evaluating Variable Expressions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Evaluate each expression for \(a=9\), \(b=-5\), and \(c=-2\).

  1. \(-b\)

Enter the value of \(-b\).

Correct! \(-(-5)=5\)

The correct answer is 5: \(-(-5)=5\).

  1. \(b^2\)

Enter the value of \(b^2\).

Correct! \((-5)^2=25\)

The correct answer is 25: \((-5)^2=25\).

  1. \(b^2−4ac\)

Enter the value of \(b^2−4ac\).

Correct! \((-5)^2−4(9)(-2)=25-(36)(-2)=25-(-72)=25+72=97\)

The correct answer is 97: \((-5)^2−4(9)(-2)=25-(36)(-2)=25-(-72)=25+72=97\).


----------------------------------------
  1. Select two answers for \(-b \pm \sqrt{a}\).

Correct! \(-(-5)+\sqrt{9}=5+3=8\) and \(-(-5)-\sqrt{9}=5-3=2\)

The correct answers are 2 and 8: \(-(-5)+\sqrt{9}=5+3=8\) and \(-(-5)-\sqrt{9}=5-3=2\)

------------------------------------

page.title: 9.7.2: Common Calculation Errors When Using the Quadratic Formula
page.contents:
Activity

Here are four equations, followed by attempts to solve them using the quadratic formula. Each attempt contains at least one error.

Solve the equations by using the quadratic formula. Then, find and describe the error(s) in the worked solutions of the same equations as the ones you solved.


  1. Equation 1: \(2x^2+3=8x\)

Here is the worked solution with errors:

Step 1
\(2x^2-8x + 3 = 0\)

Step 2
\(a=2\), \(b=-8\), \(c=3\)

Step 3
\(x=\frac {-b \pm \sqrt{ b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 4
\(x=\frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^2- (4)(2)(3)}}{2(2)}\)

Step 5
\(x=\frac {8 \pm \sqrt{ 64-24}}{4}\)

Step 6
\(x=\frac {8 \pm \sqrt{40}}{4}\)

Step 7
\(x=2 \pm \sqrt{10}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • The correct solutions are \(x=2 \pm \frac{\sqrt {40}}{4}\) or \(x=2\pm \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{10}\) or equivalent.
  • The computation from Step 6 to Step 7 is not evaluated correctly, so the solution is incorrect. \(\frac {\sqrt{40}}{4}\) is not \(\sqrt{10}\).

\(\begin{array}{l} 2 x^{2}-8 x+3=0 \\ a=2, b=-8, c=3 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^{2}-(4)(2)(3)}}{2(2)} \\ x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{64-24}}{4} \\ x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{40}}{4} \\ x=2 \pm \frac{\sqrt{40}}{4} \\ x=2 \pm \frac{\sqrt{4} \cdot \sqrt{10}}{4} \\ x=2 \pm \frac{2 \cdot \sqrt{10}}{4} \\ x=2 \pm \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{10} \end{array}\)


  1. Equation 2: \(x^2+3x=10\)

Here is the worked solution with errors:

Step 1
\(a=1\), \(b=3\), \(c=10\)

Step 2
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt {b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 3
\(x=\frac{-(3) \pm \sqrt {3^2- (4)(1)(10)}}{2(1)}\)

Step 4
\(x=\frac{-3 \pm \sqrt {9-40}}{2}\)

Step 5
\(x=\frac{-3 \pm \sqrt {-31}}{2}\)

No Solutions

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • The correct solutions are \(x=2\) and \(x=-5\).
  • The equation was not rewritten in standard form, =0, before Step 1, where the \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) were identified. The \(c\) should be -10, not 10.

\(\begin{array}{l} x^{2}+3 x-10=0 \\ a=1, b=3, c=-10 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(3) \pm \sqrt{(3)^{2}-(4)(1)(-10)}}{2(1)} \\ x=\frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9-(-40)}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9+40}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{49}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-3 \pm 7}{2} \\ x=\frac{-3+7}{2}=\frac{4}{2}=2 \\ x=\frac{-3-7}{2}=\frac{-10}{2}=-5 \end{array}\)


  1. Equation 3: \(9x^2−2x−1=0\)

Here is the worked solution with errors:

Step 1
\(a=9\), \(b= -2\), \(c= -1\)

Step 2
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 3
\(x=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2- (4)(9)(-1)}}{2}\)

Step 4
\(x=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4+36}}{2}\)

Step 5
\(x=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{40}}{2}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • The correct solution is \(x=\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{10}}{9}\) (or equivalent).
  • In step 3, the value of \(a\) is not multiplied by 2 in the denominator of the formula.

\(\begin{array}{l} a=9, b=-2, c=-1 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^{2}-(4)(9)(-1)}}{2(9)} \\ x=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4+36}}{18} \\ x=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{40}}{18} \\ x=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4} \cdot \sqrt{10}}{18} \\ x=\frac{2 \pm 2 \cdot \sqrt{10}}{2(9)} \\ x=\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{10}}{9} \end{array}\)


  1. Equation 4: \(x^2−10x+23=0\)

Here is the worked solution with errors:

Step 1
\(a=1\), \(b=-10\), \(c=23\)

Step 2
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 3
\(x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{(-10)^2- (4)(1)(23)}}{2}\)

Step 4
\(x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{-100-92}}{2}\)

Step 5
\(x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{-192}}{2}\)

No Solutions

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • The correct solution is \(x=5 \pm \sqrt{2}\) (or equivalent).
  • In Step 3, when \(b\) is -10, the value of \(-b\) should be 10.
  • In Step 4, the value of \(b^2\) should be positive even when \(b\) is negative.

\(\begin{array}{l} a=1, b=-10, c=23 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(-10) \pm \sqrt{(-10)^{2}-(4)(1)(23)}}{2} \\ x=\frac{10 \pm \sqrt{100-92}}{2} \\ x=\frac{10 \pm \sqrt{8}}{2} \\ x=5 \pm \frac{\sqrt{8}}{2} \\ x=5 \pm \frac{\sqrt{4} \cdot \sqrt{2}}{2} \\ x=5 \pm \frac{2 \cdot \sqrt{2}}{2} \\ x=5 \pm \sqrt{2} \end{array}\)

page.title: 9.7.2: Self Check
page.contents:
When solving \(x^2−30x+26=0\) using the quadratic formula, Sloane's work showed the formula as this:

\(x=\frac{-30 \pm \sqrt {900-104}}{2}\).

Which of the following describes the error in her work?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The formula states the denominator is \(2a = 2(1) =2\). So the denominator is correct. The error is that the first term in the numerator should be 30, not -30; \(x=\frac {30 \pm \sqrt{900-104}}{2}\).

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The formula states \(b^2−4ac=(-30)^2-4(1)26=900 -104\), so the discriminant is correct. The error is that the first term in the numerator should be 30, not -30; \(x=\frac {30 \pm \sqrt{900-104}}{2}\).

answer.answer_text: The first term in the numerator should be 30, not -30; \(x=\frac {30 \pm \sqrt{900-104}}{2}\).
answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: The formula states the first term in the numerator is \(-b\), so \(-b = -(-30) = 30\); \(x=\frac {30 \pm \sqrt{900-104}}{2}\).

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The formula states

\(b^2−4ac=(-30)^2-4(1)26=900 -104\), so the discriminant is correct. The error is that the first term in the numerator should be 30, not -30; \(x=\frac {30 \pm \sqrt{900-104}}{2}\).

page.title: 9.7.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Common Errors When Using the Quadratic Formula

The quadratic formula has many parts in it. A small error in any one part can lead to incorrect solutions.

Suppose we are solving \(2x^2−6=11x\). To use the formula, let's rewrite it in the form of \(ax^2+bx+c=0\), which gives: \(2x^2−11x−6=0\).

Here are some common errors to avoid:

  • Using the wrong values for \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) in the formula.

\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

\(x=\frac{-11 \pm \sqrt{(11)^2- 4(2)(-6)}}{2(2)}\)

This is incorrect! \(b\) is -11, so \(-b\) is -(-11), which is 11, not -11.

The correct formula is:
\(x=\frac{11 \pm \sqrt{(11)^2- 4(2)(-6)}}{2(2)}\)

  • Forgetting to multiply 2 by \(a\) for the denominator in the formula.

\(x=\frac{11 \pm \sqrt{(11)^2- 4(2)(-6)}}{2}\)

This is incorrect! The denominator is \(2a\), which is \(2(2)\) or 4.

The correct formula is:
\(x=\frac{11 \pm \sqrt{(11)^2- 4(2)(-6)}}{2(2)}\)

  • Forgetting that squaring a negative number produces a positive number.

\(x=\frac{11 \pm \sqrt{-121- 4(2)(-6)}}{4}\)

This is incorrect! \((-11)^2\) is 121, not -121.

The correct formula is:
\(x=\frac{11 \pm \sqrt{121- 4(2)(-6)}}{4}\)

  • Forgetting that a negative number times a positive number is a negative number.

\(x=\frac{11 \pm \sqrt{121- 48}}{4}\)

This is incorrect! \(4(2)(-6)=-48\) and \(121−(-48)\) is \(121+48\).

The correct formula is:
\(x=\frac {11 \pm \sqrt{121+48}}{4}\)

  • Making calculation errors or not following the properties of algebra.

\(x=\frac {11 \pm \sqrt{169}}{4}\)

\(x=11 \pm \sqrt{42.25}\)

This is incorrect! Both parts of the numerator, the 11 and the \(\sqrt{169}\), get divided by 4. Also, \(\frac{\sqrt{169}}{4}\) is not \(\sqrt{42.25}\).

The correct formula is:
\(x=\frac{11 \pm 13}{4}\)

Let's finish by evaluating \(\frac{11 \pm 13}{4}\) correctly:
\(x=\frac{11+13}{4}\) or \(x=\frac{11-13}{4}\)
\(x=\frac{24}{4}\) or \(x=-\frac{2}{4}\)
\(x=6\) or \(x=-\frac{1}{2}\)

To make sure our solutions are indeed correct, we can substitute the solutions back into the original equations and see whether each solution keeps the equation true.

Checking 6 as a solution:
\(2x^2-6=11x\)
\(2(6)^2-6=11(6)\)
\(2(36)-6=66\)
\(72-6=66\)
\(66=66 \; \checkmark\)

Checking \(-\frac{1}{2}\) as a solution:
\(2x^2-6=11x\)
\(2(-\frac{1}{2})^2-6=11(-\frac{1}{2})\)
\(2(\frac{1}{4})-6=-\frac{11}{2}\)
\(\frac{1}{2}-6=-5\frac{1}{2}\)
\(-5\frac{1}{2}=-5\frac{1}{2} \; \checkmark\)

We can also graph the equation \(y=2x^2−11x−6\) and find its \(x\)-intercepts to see whether our solutions to \(2x^2−11x−6=0\) are accurate (or close to accurate).

Try It: Common Errors When Using the Quadratic Formula

Zariah was solving the equation \(3x^2-8x+4=0\) with the quadratic formula and used the steps below. She then had to stop because she realized there was a problem. Locate and describe her error.

Step 1
\(x=\frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{-8^2-4(3)(4)}}{6}\)

Step 2
\(x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{-64-48}}{6}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the error:

First, Zariah substituted \(a=3\), \(b= -8\), and \(c =4\) into the formula in Step 1.

However, under the radical, \(b^2=(-8)^2= + 64\).

Step 2 would then become:

\(x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{64-48}}{6}\)

Which leads to the following solution:

\(x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{16}}{6}\)

\(x=\frac{8 \pm 4}{6}\)

\(x=\frac{12}{6}=2\), \(x=\frac{4}{6}=\frac{2}{3}\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.7.3: Different Methods of Checking Solutions of Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Activity

  1. The equation \(h(t)=2+30t−5t^2\) represents the height, as a function of time, of a pumpkin that was catapulted up in the air. Height is measured in meters and time is measured in seconds.
  1. The pumpkin reached a maximum height of 47 meters. How many seconds after launch did that happen?

Enter the number of seconds after launch.

Correct! The pumpkin reached a maximum height of 47 meters 3 seconds after launch.

The correct answer is 3. The pumpkin reached a maximum height of 47 meters 3 seconds after launch.


  1. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} h(t)=-5 t^{2}+30 t+2 \\ -5 t^{2}+30 t+2=47 \\ -5 t^{2}+30 t-45=0 \\ a=-5, b=30, c=-45 \\ t=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ t=\frac{-(30) \pm \sqrt{(30)^{2}-(4)(-5)(-45)}}{2(-5)} \\ t=\frac{-30 \pm \sqrt{900-900}}{-10} \\ t=\frac{-30}{-10} \\ t=3 \end{array}\)


  1. Suppose someone was unconvinced by your solution. Find another way (besides the steps you already took) to show your solution is correct.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Answers may vary. Sample responses include:

  • Substitute 3 for \(t\) in the original expression; evaluating it gives \(2+30(3)−5(3)^2\) or \(2+90−45\), which is 47.
  • Graphing \(y=2+30t−5t^2\) and \(y=47\) shows an intersection is located at \((3,47)\).
  • Graphing \(y=-45+30t−5t^2\) shows a zero at \((3,0)\).

  1. The equation \(r(p)=80p−p^2\) models the revenue a band expects to collect as a function of the price of one concert ticket. Ticket prices and revenues are in dollars.

A band member says that a ticket price of either $15.50 or $74.50 would generate approximately $1000 in revenue. Do you agree? Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Answers may vary. Sample responses include:

  • Partially agree. A ticket price of $15.50 will generate about $1000 in revenue, but a ticket price of $74.50 will generate much less (about $410).
  • Using the quadratic formula to solve \(1000=80p−p^2\) gives \(p \approx 15.50\) and \(p \approx 64.50\) as the solutions.
  • Substituting 15.50 into the expression \(80p−p^2\) gives 999.75, which is close to 1000. \((80(15.50)−(15.50)2=999.75)\). Substituting 74.50 into the expression \(80p−p^2\) gives 409.75.
  • Graphing the equation \(y=r(p)\) and \(y=1000\) shows two intersections at approximately \((15.50,1000)\) and \((64.50,1000)\).

Video: Explaining Your Solutions to Quadratic Situations

Watch the following video to learn more about proving quadratic solutions.



Extending Your Thinking

  1. Function \(g\) is defined by the equation \(g(t)=2+30t−5t^2−47\). Its graph opens downward.
  1. Find the zeros of function \(g\) without graphing.

Enter the zeros of function \(g\).

Compare your answer:

Function \(g\) has one zero: 3.

  1. Show your reasoning.

Enter your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

  • \(2+30t−5t^2−47\) is equivalent to \(-5t^2+30t−45\). Solving \(-5t^2+30t−45=0\) using the quadratic formula gives \(t=3\).
  • \(-5t^2+30t−45\) can be rewritten as \(-5(t^2−6t+9)\) and then as \(-5(t−3)(t−3)\). Applying the zero product property to solve \(-5(t−3)(t−3)=0\) gives \(t=3\).
  1. Explain or show how the zeros you found can tell us the vertex of the graph of \(g\).

Enter your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

Function \(g\) only has one zero, which means its graph has only one horizontal intercept, occurring when \(t=3\). Because the point \((3,0)\) is the only intercept, it must also be the vertex of the graph, otherwise there would have been either two horizontal intercepts, or none.

  1. Recall that \(g(t)=2+30t−5t^2−47\) and \(h(t)=2+30t−5t^2\). Examine these functions \(g\) and \(h\) (which defined the height of the pumpkin). Explain how the maximum of function \(h\), once we know it, can tell us the maximum of \(g\).

Enter your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

The value of the expression for \(g\) is 47 less than that of \(h\), so if we know the maximum of \(h\), we know that the maximum of \(g\) is 47 less than that. We saw that the maximum of \(h\) is 47, so the maximum of \(g\) is 47 less than 47, which is 0.

page.title: 9.7.3: Self Check
page.contents: The equation \(g(t) = 2 + 23.7t - 4.9t^2\) models the height, in meters, of a pumpkin \(t\) seconds after it has been launched from a catapult. Which of the following substitutions into the quadratic formula is correct to find the value of \(t\) where the pumpkin hit the ground?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: In the numerator, take the negative of the \(b\) value. The correct answer is \(t=\frac{-23.7 \pm \sqrt{600.89}}{-9.8}\).
That's correct! Check yourself: The quadratic formula is \(t=\frac {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\) where \(a=-4.9\), \(b=23.7\), \(c=2\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: In the denominator, be sure to multiply the \(a\) value by 2. The correct answer is \(t=\frac{-23.7 \pm \sqrt{600.89}}{-9.8}\).

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The \(a\) value is -4.9 and the \(c\) value is 2. Write the quadratic in descending order before identifying the \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\). The correct answer is \(t=\frac{-23.7 \pm \sqrt{600.89}}{-9.8}\).

page.title: 9.7.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Answering Questions About Situations With the Quadratic Formula

Here is an example of someone solving a quadratic equation that has no solutions:

Step 1
\((x+3)^2+9=0\)

Step 2
\((x+3)^2=-9\)

Step 3
\(x+3=\pm \sqrt{-9}\)

Study the example. At what point did you realize the equation had no solutions?

  • For two numbers to add up to 0, they have to be opposites. Since the number 9 is positive, the other number must be negative, which a square cannot be.

Explain how you know the equation \(49+x^2=0\) has no solutions.

  • A square is always positive, so a square plus a positive number must also be positive and can never equal zero.

Try It: Answering Questions About Situations With the Quadratic Formula

Function \(h\) models the height of an object, in meters, \(t\) seconds after it is launched into the air. It is defined by \(h(t)=-5t^2+25t\). How much time will it take the object to reach 15 meters?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve this word problem using the quadratic formula:

To know how much time it would take the object to reach 15 meters, we could solve the equation \(15=-5t^2+25t\).

  • Rewriting it in standard form gives \(-5t^2+25t-15=0\). The expression on the left side of the equation cannot be written in factored form, however.
  • Completing the square isn't convenient because the coefficient of the squared term is not a perfect square and the coefficient for the linear term is an odd number.
  • Let's use the quadratic formula, using \(a=-5\), \(b=25\), and \(c = -15\)!

Step 1
\(t=\frac {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 2
\(t=\frac{-25 \pm \sqrt{25^2- 4(-5)(-15)}}{2(-5)}\)

Step 3
\(t=\frac{-25 \pm \sqrt{325}}{-10}\)

The expression \(\frac{-25 \pm \sqrt{325}}{-10}\) represents the two exact solutions of the equation.

We can get approximate solutions by using a calculator, or by reasoning the \(\sqrt{325} \approx 18\).

The solutions tell us that there are two times after the launch when the object is at a height of 15 meters: at about 0.7 seconds (as the object is going up) and 4.3 seconds (as it comes back down).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.7.4: Practice Spotting Calculation Errors
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here is someone's solution to the equation \(3x^2−4x=20\).

Step 1
\(3x^2−4x=20\)

Step 2
\(a=3\), \(b=-4\), \(c=20\)

Step 3
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 4
\(x=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{(-4)^2- (4)(3)(20)}}{2(3)}\)

Step 5
\(x=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{-16-240}}{6}\)

Step 6
\(x=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{-256}}{6}\)

No Solutions

Identify as many errors as you can and briefly explain each error.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • \(b\) is -4, so in Step 4, the value \(-b\) should be -(-4), which is 4.
  • In Step 1, the equation should be rewritten as \(ax^2+bx+c=0\), so the constant term \(c\) is -20, not 20. So, in Step 4, the last part of the numerator should be \(\sqrt{(-4)^2-4(3)(-20)}\).
  • In Step 4, \((-4)^2\) should be 16. Squaring a negative number gives a positive number.
  • If the earlier issues were fixed, then the values under the square root symbol would be \(16+240\) or 256.

page.title: 9.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Mai and Jada are solving the equation \(2x^2−7x=15\) using the quadratic formula but found different solutions.

Mai wrote:

\(\begin{array}{l} x=\frac{-7 \pm \sqrt{(7)^{2}-4(2)(-15)}}{2(2)} \\ x=\frac{-7 \pm \sqrt{49-(-120)}}{4} \\ x=\frac{-7 \pm \sqrt{169}}{4} \\ x=\frac{-7 \pm 13}{4} \\ x=\frac{-7+13}{4}=\frac{6}{4}=\frac{3}{2} \\ x=\frac{-7-13}{4}=\frac{-20}{4}=-5 \end{array}\)

Jada wrote:

\(\begin{array}{l} x=\frac{-(-7) \pm \sqrt{(-7)^{2}-4(2)(-15)}}{2(2)} \\ x=\frac{7 \pm \sqrt{-49-(-120)}}{4} \\ x=\frac{7 \pm \sqrt{71}}{4} \end{array}\)

Answer the following questions about the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) if this equation is written in standard form, \(ax^2+bx+c=0\).

  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Correct! The value of \(a=2\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2. The value of \(a=2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Enter the value of \(b\).

Correct! The value of \(b=-7\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -7. The value of \(b=-7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

What is the value of \(c\)?

Correct! The value of \(c=-15\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -15. The value of \(c=-15\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Who has the correct solution?

Correct! Mai used 7 for \(b\) instead of -7. For \(b^2\) in the formula, Jada computed \(-7^2\) instead of \((-7)^2\), so she wrote -49 instead of 49.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.7.2–9.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

T The correct answer is: Neither one. Mai used 7 for \(b\) instead of -7. For \(b^2\) in the formula, Jada computed \(-7^2\) instead of \((-7)^2\), so she wrote -49 instead of 49. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The equation \(h(t)=-16t^2+80t+64\) represents the height, in feet, of a potato \(t\) seconds after it was launched from a mechanical device.
  1. Choose the equation that would allow us to find the time the potato hits the ground.

Correct! \(0=-16t^2+80t+64\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.7.2–9.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(0=-16t^2+80t+64\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve the equation without graphing and write it down. Enter your solution for the approximate time the potato hits the ground rounded to one decimal place.

Enter the solution for the approximate time the potato hits the ground.

Correct! \(t \approx 5.7\). Using the quadratic formula, with \(a=-16\), \(b=80\), and \(c=64\), the potato hits the ground about 5.7 seconds after being launched. (The negative solution has no meaning in this situation.)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.6.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(t \approx 5.7\). Using the quadratic formula, with \(a=-16\), \(b=80\), and \(c=64\), the potato hits the ground about 5.7 seconds after being launched. (The negative solution has no meaning in this situation.) You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Priya found \(x=3\) and \(x=-1\) as solutions to \(3x^2−6x−9=0\).
  1. If you check Priya's answer by substitution, is the answer correct?

Correct! Yes. Substituting both 3 and -1 for \(x\) in the original quadratic expression and then evaluating the expression gives a value of 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.7.2–9.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. Substituting each 3 and -1 for \(x\) in the original quadratic expression and then evaluating the expression gives a value of 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. If you check Priya's answer by graphing, is the answer correct?

Correct! Yes. Graphing the equation \(y=3x^2−6x−9\) shows \(x\)-intercepts at \((3,0)\) and \((-1,0)\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.7.2–9.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. Graphing the equation \(y=3x^2−6x−9\) shows \(x\)-intercepts at \((3,0)\) and \((-1,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. If you check Priya's answer by using the quadratic formula, is the answer correct?

Correct! Yes. Substituting 3 for \(a\), -6 for \(b\), and -9 for \(c\) in the quadratic formula gives \(x=3\) and \(x=-1\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.7.2–9.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. Substituting 3 for \(a\), -6 for \(b\), and -9 for \(c\) in the quadratic formula gives \(x=3\) and \(x=-1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A frog jumps in the air. The height, in inches, of the frog is modeled by the function \(h(t)=60t−75t^2\), where \(t\) is the time after it jumped, measured in seconds.
  1. Select two solutions to the equation \(60t−75t^2=0\).

Correct! \(t=0\), \(t=\frac{4}{5}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(t=0\), \(t=\frac{4}{5}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What do the solutions tell us about the jumping frog? Select two that apply.

Correct! The frog landed \(\frac{4}{5}\) seconds after it jumped and was on the ground again. The height of the frog was 0 inches before it jumped.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The frog landed \(\frac{4}{5}\) seconds after it jumped and was on the ground again. The height of the frog was 0 inches before it jumped.. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A tennis ball is hit straight up in the air, and its height, in feet above the ground, is modeled by the equation \(f(t)=4+12t−16t^2\), where \(t\) is measured in seconds since the ball was thrown.
  1. Select two solutions to the equation \(0=4+12t−16t^2\).

Correct! \(t=1\), \(t=-\frac{1}{4}\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(t=1\), \(t=-\frac{1}{4}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What do the solutions tell us about the tennis ball? Select two that apply.

Correct! The negative solution doesn't have meaning because a negative value for time doesn't make sense. The ball hits the ground 1 second after it is hit.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The negative solution doesn't have meaning because a negative value for time doesn't make sense. The ball hits the ground 1 second after it is hit. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Identify common errors when using the quadratic formula.
  • Describe some ways to tell if a number is a solution to a quadratic equation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.7.1: Evaluating Variable Expressions
    • In this activity, you evaluated expressions using substitution.
  • 9.7.2: Common Calculation Errors When Using the Quadratic Formula
    • In this activity, you explored how four different quadratic equations were solved by the quadratic formula. With each one, you identified the error that occurred and explained why it was an incorrect step.
    • 9.7.2: Self Check
    • 9.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.7.3: Different Methods of Checking Solutions of Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you looked at an application of quadratic equations and used the quadratic formula to prove your answer, and justify if you agreed with the answers given by a sample student.
    • 9.7.3: Self Check
    • 9.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.7.4: Practice Spotting Calculation Errors
    • In this activity, you examined an attempt to solve a quadratic equation using the quadratic formula and identified and explained all errors in the solution.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.7.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
